text.p: Cash-strapped Victorias Milling Corp denied on Monday reports in Philippine newspaper of alleged loan irregularities involving some 500 million pesos.
"The reports are not true. All the bank loans of Victorias were covered by mortgage indentures and sugar quedans (warehouses)," an official of the sugar miller told Reuters.
"The report must be referring to imported sugar in quedans used as collateral by one of Victorias' subsidiaries."
Philippine newspaper reported on Monday that some banks found recently they had been issued worthless collateral involving sugar stocks of Victorias.
The official said Victorias subsidiary North Negros Marketing Corp had sought approval from the government to release imported refined sugar in the domestic market.
State-agency Sugar Regulatory Board regulates the sale of imported sugar.
Victorias has sought a debt moratorium on its principal payment of 4.423 billion pesos from 32 foreign and local creditors due to a slump in the local sugar industry.
Victorias stocks dropped two centavos to 2.14 pesos in late trade. -- MANILA NEWSROOM (63 2) 841-8936, Fax 817-6267
